Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: I glanced at my phone, the clock blinking 7:00 p.m.—the time I always called my parents. Every week, without fail, I’d update them on my life, ask about their health, and listen to my mother’s gentle reminders to eat well and rest. Tonight, though, I was at the ambulance station, kneeling beside the open first-aid kit, checking expiration dates and counting gauze pads. My partner was waiting for my sign-off so we could be ready for the next emergency. I knew how much my parents looked forward to our calls, especially since Dad’s surgery last month. But if I rushed through the kit check, I might miss something crucial—a missing vial, an expired bandage—that could cost a patient dearly. My phone buzzed with a message from Mom: “Ready to chat when you are!” My heart twisted. I wanted to be the reliable daughter they counted on, but right now, someone else’s life might depend on my focus as an ambulance driver. I stared at the phone, torn between the two worlds, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
